abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Women in Development
            Pilot Support Project for Cote d'Ivoire was
            unsatisfactory. The project only partially achieved some of
            its objectives, institutional development was negligible,
            sustainability is uncertain, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was unsatisfactory. Several lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, a feasible timeframe for
            the necessarily sequential implementation of the
            cross-sectoral project objectives should form the outline of
            the lending program. Second, the energetic responsiveness of
            the beneficiaries to the initial rural outreach activities
            is a clear confirmation that the second and third project
            components addressed their felt needs. Third, the
            performance of the Ministry of Construction was
            unsatisfactory and compounded the already limited project
            management capacity of the PIU. Fourth, the management and
            institutional status of the IDEF satellite centers prevented
            the required iterative adjustment to client needs. Finally,
            responsibility for project monitoring would have
            strengthened the role and credibility of the
            Interministerial Committee.
